ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how stars, galaxies, universe form and evolve.
I learned some basic history of Astronomy, principles of Cosmology, calculations for distances, sizes, luminosity, and more within the universe.
Astronomy, learned about the lifecycle of stars, black holes, some history of astronomy, relativity, different types of stars, qualities of the universe, telescopes,  the Big-bang etc...
Basic concepts of astronomy, from stars to cosmology
Lots of equation memorization
Gained an understanding of the basics of astronomy, learned how to manage completion of problem sets every week

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Lectures well broken down into different topics related to the galaxies and the universe.
Sometimes homework problems were not covered during lectures before due date.

This course is marketed as introductory and graspable for students from non-STEM backgrounds but this was not the case. Extra credit opportunities, more helpful office hours, and more exam preparation would have made worlds of difference.

The only "weakness" might be difficult interacting throughout the lecture or staying focused, but it was probably because of it being online. It's hard to gauge when I don't have a frame of reference. I do think that the weekly sessions were very helpful in understanding the homework/equations more deeply.

Strengths: well-taught, a good class to see if you want to major in astronomy, but also a manageable class to take for credit, especially if you've had previous experience in astronomy, concepts are fairly straightforward too 
Weaknesses: there is a lot of information to take in per lecture, it's not necessarily hard but there is quite a bit
More in depth working with equations instead of just learning them and having to apply without practice on psets

The lectures were engaging and interesting. The discussion of the history of astronomy was in depth and intriguing. 

More emphasis on math and the a larger focus on the prep for the psets would have been helpful. This class math heavy and challenging for non stem majors.

Both professor and TF available for questions, pace of the course allows for understanding of topics
Problem sets require students to do some independent learning (from textbook) to complete

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures and lecture slides were provided, which was very helpful.

Professors Zin probably had the best pre made slides out of all my professors this semester, their clear, useful and present key info without dragging on too much. He also took care to properly expand upon all topics, so its not like we zoomed though material at an unusually fast pace due to the online format.

I think the course did a great job gearing toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic. I went to most live lectures but they were additionally recorded for student benefit. Also consistent and available during office hours and discussion sections.
Recorded lectures and multiple office hour opportunities helped

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, super interesting contents and lectures are very well taught.
Absolutely not. I felt consistently lost and reliant on the textbook which only loosely mirrored what the professor wanted us to learn for the quizzes.
Yes, it was very interesting and a nice course for an introduction principles of physics for those who may not be science-driven learners.

It's a fun course, and this is from the perspective of someone who didn't even get to the whole telescope viewing part due to the online format. Give it a go! The math is accessible enough that anyone should be able to do the psets. Despite being an intro course it never felt like what we were doing was boring; on the contrary some of the topics were quite complex (ie. relativity, cosmic microwave background, cosmological redshift etc.). Psets are usually pretty easy, but since is a astronomy course, numbers are often huge or tiny (stuff like 1.26E-34 m instead of simpler numbers) so I'd recommend checking stuff over with a friend even if you're confident. Lectures are pretty cookie cutter, you just sit and listen, but the content is pretty interesting (or when its not, it's easy enough that you only have to half listen) so it's fine. I think the course introduces a lot of large topics that recur alot, so you'll retain a of info! If you want to know more about the stars and space take it! I've literally no complaints about this course... except that the final was a tad long.
Yes

If you're interested in astronomy, either trying to figure out if it might be good to major in or just want to learn more about astronomy, this course is pretty good for you. If you've taken astronomy courses in the past though, the class is really a breeze. And if you have never learned anything about astronomy, the concepts introduced aren't really hard at all, but there's a lot of concepts to go through.
If they were a mathematics major
This was a great course for fulfilling the science/QR distributional requirement as a humanities major. Very interesting subject and the math portion was taught well at a good pace.
Yes, it is a course at Yale, in terms of material, that isn't rivaled elsewhere.
Would recommend this course to students interested in astronomymay be too difficult to keep track of if the topics are dreary

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lecture
Weekly discussion sections
Aside from the lectures there was also a lot of individual textbook work.
Combination of live virtual lectures and recorded lectures
